dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Not a single U.S. city in the top ten of the Global Liveability Index? That seems a bit harsh.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not a single U.S. city in the top ten of the Global Liveability Index? That seems a bit harsh.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the Global Liveability Index, a measurement of the world's best cities to call home, not a single U.S. city was good enough to make the cut.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but it's not that they're getting worse—other cities are just improving faster. Like, Vienna took the top spot, and Canada had three cities in the top ten.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but it's not that they're getting worse-other cities are just improving faster. Like, Vienna took the top spot, and Canada had three cities in the top ten.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That doesn't necessarily mean that U.S. cities are getting worse. It just means that other cities on the scale are getting better compared to one another. The best city to live was Vienna, Austria. Canada had three cities, by comparison, including Calgary (3), Vancouver (6) and Toronto (7).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But Honolulu was the highest-ranked American city, right? I mean, that's still something.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Honolulu was the highest-ranked American city, right? I mean, that's still something.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The best American city on a global scale was Honolulu.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Sure, but it's all relative. The index looks at things like infrastructure, safety, healthcare… and big global hubs like New York or London just struggle with congestion and crime.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sure, but it's all relative. The index looks at things like infrastructure, safety, healthcare... and big global hubs like New York or London just struggle with congestion and crime.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Global Liveability Index compares world cities with each other in terms of security, affordability, education, healthcare, its urban lifestyle and infrastructure. But each one has higher levels of crime and congestion that make them much less liveable than their peers in the top 10.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, but then how did Copenhagen sneak into the top ten? It's a capital city too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, but then how did Copenhagen sneak into the top ten? It's a capital city too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Other than Vienna, only one other European city made the top 10. Copenhagen is considered ninth-most-liveable city in the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's about balance—midsize cities in wealthy countries with lower density tend to score better. Six of the top ten are actually in Australia and Canada.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's about balance-midsize cities in wealthy countries with lower density tend to score better. Six of the top ten are actually in Australia and Canada.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Those that score best tend to be midsize cities in wealthier countries. Six of the top 10 scoring cities are in Australia and Canada where population densities are lower.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So it's not just about being a business center with all the amenities.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So it's not just about being a business center with all the amenities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Those places often have overburdened infrastructure. Even cities like Auckland and Perth dropped out of the top ten this year, despite not really getting worse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Those places often have overburdened infrastructure. Even cities like Auckland and Perth dropped out of the top ten this year, despite not really getting worse.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The big city buzz comes with heavily burdened infrastructure, poverty and higher crime rates. At least four worldclass cities have fallen from the top 10 over the past yearAuckland (from 8th to 12th), Perth (from 7th to 14th), Helsinki (from 9th to 16th) and Hamburg (from 10th to 18th)despite the fact that none of these cities have seen a deterioration of the main items being measured.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, so the rankings shift just because other cities improve? That feels a little arbitrary.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, so the rankings shift just because other cities improve? That feels a little arbitrary.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Changes in liveability rankings elsewhere can impact on the rankings of individual cities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's, but there's a pattern—the best scorers offer cultural activities without high crime or crowding. Western Europe still has nine of the top twenty, though.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's, but there's a pattern-the best scorers offer cultural activities without high crime or crowding. Western Europe still has nine of the top twenty, though.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Plus they have a number of cultural and recreational activities attractive to residents without having high crime levels and overburdened infrastructure. Western Europe has 9 of the top 20 cities, and 26 of the top 66 cities with average scores on things like infrastructure and safety of over 80%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but what about emerging markets? Any standouts?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but what about emerging markets? Any standouts?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Buenos Aires is top there at 62nd, ahead of Moscow and St. Petersburg. Rio even outranks São Paulo, which is wild given Rio's crime issues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Buenos Aires is top there at sixty second, ahead of Moscow and St. Petersburg. Rio even outranks São Paulo, which is wild given Rio's crime issues.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Within the emerging market cityscape, Buenos Aires is the best of show (62), followed by Moscow (68) and St. Petersburg (70). Rio de Janeiro (88) ranks higher than São Paulo (93), which is surprising given its massive problem with violent crime.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Really? Because of its size and climate?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Really? Because of its size and climate?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, compactness and cultural offerings apparently give it an edge, even with the violence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, compactness and cultural offerings apparently give it an edge, even with the violence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The general compactness of the city, and an overall better offering of cultural attractions and climate make it better than the less violent, but too big, too congested, and too wet São Paulo.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm. I guess liveability's more nuanced than I thought.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm. I guess liveability's more nuanced than I thought.
